title: GAIN Trial: A Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Study of COR388 in Subjects With Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study that assessed the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of 2 dose levels of COR388 in subjects with a clinical diagnosis of mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease (AD) dementia.
description_detailed:
This was a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study that assessed the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of 2 dose levels of COR388 oral capsules in subjects with probable Alzheimer's disease (AD) dementia according to the National Institute on Aging-Alzheimer's Association (NIA-AA) criteria. The subject did not have other conditions or brain imaging abnormalities that could explain the symptoms of dementia. All subjects were encouraged to have lumbar punctures (LPs) (during screening, week 24 and week 48) in the absence of medical conditions that could increase the risk of the procedure in the opinion of the Investigator. Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF), saliva, and blood were analyzed for measurements of biomarkers of AD and neuroinflammation, and for the presence of bacterial deoxyribonucleic acid (DNA) of Porphyromonas gingivalis (P. gingivalis). A subset of sites monitored subjects for clinical evidence of periodontitis at baseline, 24 and 48 weeks.

The study consisted of 3 phases: a screening phase of up to 6 weeks, a treatment phase of up to 48 weeks, and a safety follow-up phase of 6 weeks.

participantFlowModule.preAssignmentDetails: Randomized subjects were stratified by baseline Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) score (MMSE ≥12 and ≤18, and MMSE ≥19 and ≤24) and Apolipoprotein E genotype (ApoE4 positive either homozygous or heterozygous vs. all others) to assure balanced distribution of mild and moderate Alzheimer's disease and a balanced distribution of ApoE4 subjects, across treatment arms.
participantFlowModule.recruitmentDetails: A total of 89 centers worldwide screened subjects and included 57 centers in the United States, 9 centers in the United Kingdom, 8 centers in Spain, 7 centers in Poland, 5 centers in France, and 3 centers in the Netherlands.

categories.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcomeMeasures.title: Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-Cognitive Subscale 11 (ADAS-Cog 11)
outcomeMeasures.description: Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-Cognitive Subscale 11 (ADAS-Cog 11) - Total Score The cognitive subscale of the ADAS (ADAS Cog11) was used as a primary efficacy measure and consists of 11 items assessing areas of function most typically impaired in Alzheimer's disease (AD): orientation, verbal memory, language, and praxis. he scale ranges from 0 to 70, with higher scores indicating greater disease severity.

analyses.pValueComment: The interim analysis was conducted at significance level of 0.05 and the significance level was adjusted for final analysis.

outcomeMeasures.title: Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study Group-Activities of Daily Living (ADCS-ADL)
outcomeMeasures.description:
The Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study Activities of Daily Living (ADCS-ADL) Inventory Score is a 23-item inventory.

The ADCS-ADL measures both basic and instrumental activities of daily living The total ADCS-ADL score ranges from 0 to 78, with lower scores indicating greater disease severity.

outcomeMeasures.title: Clinical Dementia Rating-Sum of Boxes (CDR-SB)
outcomeMeasures.description:
Clinical Dementia Rating-Sum of Boxes (CDR-SB) - Sum of Boxes CDR-SB is a semi-structured interview of participants and their caregivers. Participant's cognitive status is rated across 6 domains of functioning, including memory, orientation, judgment/problem solving, community affairs, home/hobbies, and personal care.

Severity score assigned for each of 6 domains; total score (SB) ranges from 0 to 18. Higher scores indicate greater disease severity.

outcomeMeasures.title: Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE)
outcomeMeasures.description: Change in Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) - Total Score Minimum Score - 0 Maximum Score - 30 Higher score means better outcome

outcomeMeasures.title: Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI)
outcomeMeasures.description:
Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI) - Total Score NPI assesses psychopathology in participants with dementia and other neurologic disorders.

Total score ranges from 12 to 144; higher scores indicate greater disease severity.

outcomeMeasures.title: Anti-P. Gingivalis IgG in Serum
outcomeMeasures.description:
Anti-P. gingivalis immunoglobulin G (IgG) in serum

Antibody levels were measured by ELISA and outcome measure are ELISA UNITS (EU)

Lower levels represent a pharmacodynamic effect of the drug on its target

outcomeMeasures.title: Magnetic Resonance Imaging
outcomeMeasures.description:
Change in magnetic resonance imaging - bilateral whole brain volume

Larger volume may represent effect of the drug on its target

outcomeMeasures.title: Periodontal (or Gum) Pocket Depth
outcomeMeasures.description:
Periodontal (or gum) pocket depth - pocket depth for only sites with depth \>= 4mm.

The primary endpoint was mean change in pocket depth from baseline to the end of the double-blind treatment period for tooth sites with depth ≥ 4mm at any time during the study. Therefore, values presented may be less than 4mm.

Larger measure means worse outcome

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: Adverse event data were collected from screening through 48 weeks of treatment and 6 weeks of follow up, a total of approximately 60 weeks.

seriousEvents.organSystem: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

certainAgreement.otherDetails: Individual investigators and/or their associates may publish findings of this study in scientific journals or present them at scientific meetings, provided the Sponsor is given ample opportunity to review any proposed abstract, manuscript, or slide presentation before its submission.

explanation_target: Reason: The trial drug is COR388 (nonproprietary name atuzaginstat), an oral, brain-penetrant, irreversible lysine-gingipain inhibitor that targets toxic protease virulence factors produced by the bacterium Porphyromonas gingivalis — an upstream pathological hypothesis for Alzheimer’s disease. This indicates a disease-modifying approach aimed at Alzheimer’s pathology rather than a symptomatic cognitive enhancer or neuropsychiatric treatment. citeturn1search2turn1search1

Act: Extracted trial details — GAIN (NCT03823404) is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled Phase 2/3 study in mild–moderate AD testing two dose levels (40 mg and 80 mg twice daily) of COR388 versus placebo for 48 weeks. The investigational agent is explicitly described in multiple sources as a small-molecule gingipain (lysine protease) inhibitor (atuzaginstat / COR388). citeturn0search6turn0search0turn1search6

Reflect: Classification check — because atuzaginstat/COR388 is a small-molecule protease inhibitor designed to modify disease-associated pathology (gingipain-mediated pathology), it fits the definition of a disease-targeted small molecule. It is not a biologic (e.g., monoclonal antibody or vaccine), not described as a symptomatic cognitive enhancer, and not focused on neuropsychiatric symptom management. No contradictory details were found in the trial description. citeturn1search2turn1search1

- ALZFORUM entry: atuzaginstat (COR388) listed as a small molecule gingipain inhibitor; trial and development notes. citeturn1search1
- Review/PMC article summarizing atuzaginstat pharmacology (irreversible lysine-gingipain inhibitor), preclinical and clinical rationale. citeturn1search2
- Clinical trial registry / trial summary for GAIN (NCT03823404) with official title and study description. citeturn0search6
- DrugBank / company release confirming atuzaginstat (COR388) identity and modality (small molecule) and INN assignment. citeturn1search6turn1search5
explanation_agent: Reason: COR388 (atuzaginstat) is an oral, brain‑penetrant small‑molecule irreversible inhibitor of lysine‑gingipain proteases produced by the bacterium Porphyromonas gingivalis — i.e., it targets a bacterial virulence factor (the gingipain protease) as an upstream, pathogen‑based hypothesis for Alzheimer’s disease rather than a canonical host molecular pathway such as amyloid, tau, ApoE/lipids, synaptic receptors, or host proteostasis machinery. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Act: Extracted trial details — the GAIN trial (NCT03823404) is/was a randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled Phase 2/3 study of COR388 (atuzaginstat) in mild–moderate AD (two dose levels 40 mg and 80 mg BID, 48 weeks, ~643 participants), and multiple sources describe COR388 as a small‑molecule gingipain (lysine protease) inhibitor developed to block P. gingivalis gingipain activity. citeturn0search4turn0search6turn0search3

Reflect: Mapping to CADRO — CADRO categories A–Q predominantly describe therapeutic targets within host biology (amyloid beta, tau, ApoE/lipids, inflammation, proteostasis of host proteins, synaptic receptors, etc.). Because COR388’s primary molecular target is a bacterial virulence protease (gingipain) rather than a host AD protein/pathway, it does not fit neatly into those host‑centric CADRO categories. While gingipain activity is reported to drive downstream host effects (neuroinflammation, increased Aβ, tau changes), the direct molecular target of the drug is microbial (infection/virulence factor). Therefore the most appropriate CADRO assignment is T) Other (therapeutic target outside the standard CADRO host pathway categories). Relevant sources describing the gingipain target, preclinical effects on Aβ/inflammation, and trial design are cited below. citeturn0search2turn0search1
- ALZFORUM entry summarizing atuzaginstat/COR388 mechanism and GAIN trial details. citeturn0search0
- PubMed review/article describing atuzaginstat as a gingipain inhibitor and the bacterial hypothesis linking P. gingivalis to AD pathology. citeturn0search1
- Dominy et al./related PubMed work describing P. gingivalis/gingipains in AD brains and preclinical data showing gingipain inhibition reduces Aβ and neuroinflammation. citeturn0search2
- Clinical trial registry / summary for GAIN (NCT03823404) with official trial design and dosing. citeturn0search4
- Conference/journal update and baseline description of the Phase 2/3 GAIN trial (Cortexyme publications/abstracts). citeturn0search6
